content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice, short and clean. Thanks!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy to understand puzzle, just some small edits and it's good to go ðŸ‘

I don't love the required output for empty set, feels kind of strange to code an empty set as {} but a regular set as space separated... probably there's a good reason for it but I would have expected empty line or "empty" as string...


also, the generated header is confusing and adds no real info, I would eliminate it :
/**
 * + - *
 **/

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It was fun to do :)

I did it in 10 minutes, because I missread the subject but after my reread technically I did in 3-4min of code.

I did in 2 minutes "+" and "-". And I block 6-7 minutes because I only read the first part of the sentence "difference", I thought it was : the set contains all single number contained by only one set.

But after reread the explanation I did in less of one minute.

```js
switch (operation) {
    case '+': answer(new Set([...set1, ...set2])); return
    case '&': answer(set1.filter((a) => set2.indexOf(a) !== -1)); return
    case '-': answer(set1.filter((a) => set2.indexOf(a) === -1)); return
}
```
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
In my opinion, the exercise is great but giving the two sets and operator in a single line adds a lot of manipulation not fit for a clash of code and a little hard for some people

* I'm not in favour of using the symbols "+", "-" and "&", because your code shows that they can be directly used in the Ruby solution code. That can be similarly done in Python for "-" and "&".

Suggest to use some other symbols instead (e.g. U, D, C).

Stub generator
* You may delete the statement. It isn't necessary to include any statement in the default code.

Thanks.

Thanks.

I understand the logic with changing symbols and at first I used "*" instead of "&", but I decided that in order for this to be solvable in Reverse I really wanted to use symbols that were easiest to decipher their meaning. "&" makes sense for intersections because it's got to be in set_1 and set_2. Then plus and minus are also just the natural choices. I think the small benefit to Ruby users is less of a big deal than obscuring the challenge to the point that Reverse is not fun anymore.

As for the statement in the stub, I mostly just can't stand the "Auto-generated code..." default text that takes up so much space. I always remove it for aesthetics when I clash, so I like to have a shorter statement in mine so that people can save time on removing it if they hate it too, haha.

Thanks for the feedback.
Would this format be your preference?
+
1 2 4
3 5

I guess I felt that the actual set operations are something the better clashers could solve in about 2 minutes, so I thought making the string manipulation a bit more complicated would help make it more of a ~5 minute challenge.

Thanks, I left the "{}" in because it's the way that an empty set is represented in mathematics. I've changed the header now to just say who the author is, I mostly just want a header so that the long auto-generated one isn't there, because I personally find that one annoying and always spend time removing it to make my code nicer. I figure having the author in the code can help for Reverse mode where you sometimes want to find the clash afterwards and figure out what the solution was if you couldn't solve it in time. :)

Sure, you're right, good clashers can solve that quite easily.
I don't really know if adding this manipulation is great or not. We'll need other opinions about the changes I proposed.

I decided to go through with your suggestion.
Made it 3 lines with the operation in the middle.
